prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CDFS Sample
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: AGN with Lx (2-8KeV) > 1.e44 ergs s-1 and 2<z<2.5. Selected as in Page et al. 2012. With parent Chandra sample from Lehmer et al. 2005 and spec-z from Silverman et al. 2010

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We will measure continuum fluxes and scale these to mono-chromatic luminosities and assume SEDs to infer a total LFIR. Uncertainties in scaling from mono L to LFIR come from uncertainties in the SED which add to the measurement uncertainties in the flux from the whole observing system (sigma_inst).
We estimated the calibration (Lmono/LFIR) uncertainty from an SED analysis of complete samples of HerMES galaxies (Symeonidis et al. 2013). This gives us an uncertainty at any observed wavelength. At these redshifts z~2.25 Band 7 is 270um and Band 9 is 135um. This calibration error is higher in Band 7 (~75%) than at Band 9 (~36%).
We have then explored the error in LIR that we would get combing the calibration uncertainity with the sigma_inst (added in quadrature). Assuming Band 9 fluxes are 5X brighter. We find that for the same observing time Band 7 is more efficient, i.e. we have a lower total error in LIR for the same observing time. Also Band 7 is less weather prone than Band 9.
Thus we are requesting continuum observations in Band 7 as this is the most efficient probe of obscured star formation at this redshift.
To assess the required number of targets and sigma_inst. We have taken the approach of comparing the observed flux distribution with models of what that flux distribution might be. We explored 3 models of underlying 870um flux distribution consistent with the observed mu =0.67mJy, sigma_pop=1.0mJy and consistent with the scatter in fluxes due to SED variation as above. These three models are described in the science case. We sampled these models with AGN samples of different sizes N_samp and with different sigma_inst. We varied N_samp (in units of 15 targets, 30-90) and sigma_inst (0.1,0.134,0.2 mJy). We found that 0.134mJy and 45 targets gave the best results i.e. with a K-S test sensitivity of better than 95% with the lowest total observatory time.
Our requested sensitivity of 0.134~mJy also gives SNR=5 detections on the mean flux and provides adequate constraints on our models for 45 galaxies (see Table 1 and Fig. 2).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: COSMOS Sample
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: AGN with Lx > 1.e44 ergs s-1. 2<z<2.5 Selected from COSMOS sample with spec-z as given in Ciavano et al. 2012. Randomly sampled to give 36 sources.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We will measure continuum fluxes and scale these to mono-chromatic luminosities and assume SEDs to infer a total LFIR. Uncertainties in scaling from mono L to LFIR come from uncertainties in the SED which add to the measurement uncertainties in the flux from the whole observing system (sigma_inst).
We estimated the calibration (Lmono/LFIR) uncertainty from an SED analysis of complete samples of HerMES galaxies (Symeonidis et al. 2013). This gives us an uncertainty at any observed wavelength. At these redshifts z~2.25 Band 7 is 270um and Band 9 is 135um. This calibration error is higher in Band 7 (~75%) than at Band 9 (~36%).
We have then explored the error in LIR that we would get combing the calibration uncertainity with the sigma_inst (added in quadrature). Assuming Band 9 fluxes are 5X brighter. We find that for the same observing time Band 7 is more efficient, i.e. we have a lower total error in LIR for the same observing time. Also Band 7 is less weather prone than Band 9.
Thus we are requesting continuum observations in Band 7 as this is the most efficient probe of obscured star formation at this redshift.
To assess the required number of targets and sigma_inst. We have taken the approach of comparing the observed flux distribution with models of what that flux distribution might be. We explored 3 models of underlying 870um flux distribution consistent with the observed mu =0.67mJy, sigma_pop=1.0mJy and consistent with the scatter in fluxes due to SED variation as above. These three models are described in the science case. We sampled these models with AGN samples of different sizes N_samp and with different sigma_inst. We varied N_samp (in units of 15 targets, 30-90) and sigma_inst (0.1,0.134,0.2 mJy). We found that 0.134mJy and 45 targets gave the best results i.e. with a K-S test sensitivity of better than 95% with the lowest total observatory time.
Our requested sensitivity of 0.134~mJy also gives SNR=5 detections on the mean flux and provides adequate constraints on our models for 45 galaxies (see Table 1 and Fig. 2).

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Submillimetre observations from Herschel show that while rapid star formation was common in the host galaxies of AGN (seen in the X-ray by Chandra) at 1<z<3, the most vigorous star formation is not observed around black holes above an X-ray luminosity of 1e44 ergs s-1 (Page et al., 2012). Deeper analysis from stacking shows that star formation is present in at least some highly X-ray luminous systems but there is significant variation between samples (Page et al. 2012, Harrison et al. 2012). This suppression of star formation in the host galaxies of powerful AGN is a key prediction of models in which the AGN drives an outflow, expelling the interstellar medium of its host and transforming the galaxies' properties in a brief period of cosmic time ~< 1e8 years. We now propose ALMA Band 7 continuum observations to measure the distribution of residual dust-obscured star formation to understand the nature of this suppression in a complete sample of 45 powerful AGN in a narrow z range (2<z<2.5). Specifically, we will investigate whether the suppression is ubiquitous or bi-modal (i.e. whether some systems are significantly more suppressed than others)
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2012.1.00845.S The nature of the supression of star formation by powerful AGN. Oliver
